title: math.Pow() slowness
body:
by **caglar@10ur.org**: 
go-nuts thread: https://groups.google.com/d/msg/golang-nuts/GOviOxfkt2E/FMZ894wTIMAJ

go version: go version devel +bca0032e86af Wed Feb 26 13:20:36 2014 +1100 darwin/amd64

Summary of the problem:

Was profiling some code and profiler showed that I was spending a huge amount of time
inside the math.Pow function. I decided to write the following benchmark to see whatâ€™s
going on (attached to the report)

Running the benchmark on my 2GHz Intel Core i7 laptop (OSX 10.9.1) with latest go showed
following;

go test -bench=.
testing: warning: no tests to run
PASS
BenchmarkUnrollTrue 100000000         24.8 ns/op
BenchmarkUnrollFalse 10000000       254 ns/op
ok  _/Users/sonur/g/pow 41.491s

After some back and forth in mailing list, I tried adding following special case to pow
function

--- a/src/pkg/math/pow.go	Wed Feb 26 13:20:36 2014 +1100
+++ b/src/pkg/math/pow.go	Wed Feb 26 00:23:10 2014 -0500
@@ -41,6 +41,8 @@
 		return 1
 	case y == 1:
 		return x
+	case y == 2:
+		return x*x
 	case y == 0.5:
 		return Sqrt(x)
 	case y == -0.5:

which improved the situation

go test -bench=.
testing: warning: no tests to run
PASS
BenchmarkUnrollTrue	100000000	        27.5 ns/op
BenchmarkUnrollFalse	50000000	        46.9 ns/op
ok  	_/Users/sonur/g/pow	54.729s


I understand that it's not feasible or possible to add every case into math.Pow
function's fast-path but on the other hand 10x slowness didn't sound right. Dave Cheney
suggested me to raise an issue to discuss so I am  wondering whether you are open to add
additional special cases into pow function or considering this as an expected outcome of
using a generic function?
Attachments: 1. pow_test.go (1150 bytes)
